awd_titl_txt: Postdoctoral Research:Science and the Permitting Process for Resource Extraction
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will be carried out by a postdoctoral fellow trained in Environmental Engineering and mentored by an environmental sociologist. The PI will study the permitting process for the Pebble Partnership 2013-2015, and the resulting scientific, policy, legal, and ethical controversies raised by the project.

The results will provide useful knowledge for science and technology studies and regulatory science.

por.por_cntn:
The Governance of Science and Technology in the Permitting Process of Industrial-Scale Resource Extraction: The Case of the Proposed Pebble Mine in Bristol Bay, Alaska  (PI: Bindu Panikkar) 150,000;  8/7/13-8/31/14 and 8/17/16 - 11/31/17 This project examined the governance of risks in the permitting of newly proposed mines in Alaska. Intellectual Merit: In this research we compared the dynamics of the different material cultures in the Bristol Bay region within the scope of the permitting process of the proposed Pebble Mine. We started with the early permitting debates to understand the contemporary politics of defining and constructing dominant resource materialities. We also examined alternative regimes of value and counter-discursive renewable material realities created in tandem for consideration by social, environmental, and community groups. This project built the theoretical framework of resource material imaginaries; it broadened the theoretical framework of STS and law with concepts in legal pluralism, and environmental justice to examine the legal contentions within the Pebble Mine Permitting; evaluated health impact assessment utilizing social theories of risk, a voluntary assessment conducted as part of Environmental Impact Statement; and compared public engagement and democratic practices within permitting between Pebble Mine in Bristol Bay and Donlin Mine in the Kuskwokwin Region in Alaska. We showed that civic epistemologies and ontologies embedded in different social, scientific and political practices help explain environmental actions and outcomes, that construction of resource materialities is characterized by the operationalization of disparate (but overlapping) material cultures and knowledge traditions. We show that these divergent discourses by the public construct deliberative valuation of alternative futures in resource extractive communities, though these public imaginations of alternative futures are not effectively considered in the permitting process.

 Broader Impacts: Graduate mentoring, community engagement, local and conference presentations at the 4S, AGU, Arctic Net, and Arctic Frontiers. Publications: This project has generated two peer reviewed journal articles in review (Panikkar, in review at Social Studies of Science, and Science as Culture) and the PI has two working drafts under preparation which will be submitted by the end of the year.
